title-group.article-title: Antegrade Versus Retrograde: Letter to the Editor

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

body.p: We have been reviewing articles on osteochondritis dissecans of knee for our journal club. There seems to be a contradiction of what is antegrade and what is retrograde drilling of lesions in the following 2 articles:

list-item.p: In Boughanem et al, “Functional and Radiologic Outcomes of Juvenile Osteochondritis Dissecans of Knee Treated With Extra-Articular Retrograde Drilling,”1 the images in Figure 2 (p 2215) show drilling from outside and is said to be retrograde drilling.

In Kocher et al, “Management of Osteochondritis Dissecans of the Knee,”2 the image in Figure 3 (p 1185) and the statement that channels are created in the articular surface (p 1188) indicate to me that retrograde drilling is from inside the joint.

body.p: It seems that the 2 descriptions are contradictory. In addition, I have asked several orthopaedic surgeons how they use the terms and no one can agree. My question is, which one is right and which one is wrong?

We need to standardize the definitions. I think it is confusing. When one does antegrade intramedullary fixation of a femoral shaft fracture, it is done from proximal to distal. If such is done from the knee up, it is retrograde drilling.

sig-block.sig: David Drez Jr, MD Lake Charles, Louisiana

ref.citation: BoughanemJ RiazR PatelRM SarwarkJF . Functional and radiographic outcomes of juvenile osteochondritis dissecans of the knee treated with extra-articular retrograde drilling. Am J Sports Med. 2011;39:2212-2217.
KocherMS TuckerR GanleyTJ FlynnJM . Management of osteochondritis dissecans of the knee: current concepts review. Am J Sports Med. 2006;34:1181-1191.

body.p: This is a question that was discussed internally amongst the authors as well as with other surgeons at our institution prior to publication. The answer really depends on a few factors.

When we first wrote the manuscript we described our technique as antegrade because the drilling occurred proximal to distal relative to the longitudinal axis of the limb. It turns out that most sports surgeons as well as the AJSM reviewers do not discuss antegrade versus retrograde based on the direction of drilling relative to the extremity, but rather to the lesion. As we approached the osteochondritis dissecans lesion from behind, it is called retrograde drilling. When drilling from the articular surface it should be called antegrade.

Our definition of retrograde drilling is the more commonly accepted definition based on our discussions, but certainly people may base their definition on the direction of drilling relative to the extremity.
